byline.contributor: Steven Lee Myers reported from Washington, and Neil MacFarquhar from Moscow. Andrew E. Kramer contributed reporting from Moscow, David M. Herszenhorn from Washington, and Doris Burke from New York.
byline.original: By STEVEN LEE MYERS and NEIL MacFARQUHAR

abstract: Breach of thousands of emails on eve of Democratic National Convention prompts question of whether Russian Pres Vladimir V Putin is backing Donald Trump; many note that Trump's campaign chairman Paul Manafort has had extensive financial and political dealings with business executives in Russia and Ukraine, and Trump himself turned to advisers who share his views on Russia at beginning of his presidential campaign.
lead_paragraph: A breach tied to Russian intelligence agencies has raised questions about whether the Kremlin has thrown its support behind Donald J. Trump.

headline.main: To Democrats, Email Hack Suggests Trump Has New Supporter: Putin
headline.print_headline: Seeing in Email Breach a Trump-Putin Alliance

snippet: A breach tied to Russian intelligence agencies has raised questions about whether the Kremlin has thrown its support behind Donald J. Trump....
